text: The origin of social and preventive medicine dates back to the: 17th century 18th century 16th century 19th century
explanation:
:
The origin of social and preventive medicine dates back to the 18th century. It began even before the germ theory had been proposed.

text: Which medicine claims to be the world’s first organized body of medical knowledge? Indian Chinese Egyptian Mesopotamian
explanation:
:
Chinese medicine claims to be the world's first organized body of medical knowledge. It dates back to 2700 B.C. They are also considered to be the pioneers of immunization (used variolation against smallpox).
Modern Chinese medicine includes barefoot doctors and acupuncture.

text: All of the following are true about the ministry of AYUSH except: It was formed in 2014 in India for education and research on AYUSH It aims to mainstream AYUSH as part of the National Rural Health Mission It was previously known as department of Indian system of medicine and homeopathy It regulates the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, Homeopathy and Siddha only
explanation:
:
The Ministry of AYUSH was established to regulate the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy.
It was formed in 2014 in India for the development of education and research in AYUSH. It was previously known as the Department of Indian System of Medicine and Homeopathy (ISM&H). It aims to mainstream AYUSH as part of the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
The Ayurveda, Siddha, and Yoga systems of medicine are of Indian origin. Ayurveda means knowledge of life. Its origin can be traced back to 5000 B.C (Vedic times). The medical knowledge in the Atharvaveda eventually developed into Ayurveda.
The Unani system is of Greek origin.

text: Samuel Hahnemann is referred to as the founding father of: Ayurveda Homeopathy Unani Naturopathy
explanation:
:
Samuel Hahnemann is the founding father of homeopathy. He was German. There are 3 principles in homeopathy:
Similia similibus curentur or human drug pathogenicity study: Treatment of disease using small amounts of drug that, in healthy people, would produce similar symptoms of the disease itself.
A single medicine is used for the treatment.
The minimum dose of the drug should be used.

text: The Tridosha theory of disease explains disease as a disturbance in the equilibrium of the three humors. To which system of medicine does this theory belong to? Ayurveda Homeopathy Siddha Unani – Tibb
explanation:
:
Tridosha theory of disease belongs to Ayurveda. It explains disease as a disturbance in the equilibrium of the three humors, namely:
Vata (wind)

Pitta (gall)
Kapha (mucus).
A healthy person has a perfect balance of these humors.
This theory is similar to the Unani-tibb system of medicine which is based on four humors.

text: Which system of medicine originated in Tamil–speaking areas in south India? Ayurveda Naturopathy Unani – Tibb Siddha
explanation:
:
The Siddha system of medicine originated from Tamil culture. It means achievement.
This system believes that sociodemographic, psychological, and physiological factors related to a person must be taken into account while deciding the medical treatment. They believe that disease is a disturbance in the equilibrium of three humors called vaadham, pittam, and kapham.

text: Where did the Unani–Tibb system of medicine originate? Egypt China Greece Mesopotamia
explanation:
:
The Unani-Tibb system of medicine originated in ancient Greece.
The Greeks believed that matter was made up of four elements. These elements had certain qualities that were represented in the body by the 4 humors and also determined the person's temperament.

text: Inoculating a person with a small amount of infective material to obtain protection against it was first pioneered by: Robert Koch Edward Jenner Louis Pasteur Chinese medicine
explanation:
:
The procedure described is immunization. It was first pioneered in ancient Chinese medicine. They practiced variolation to prevent smallpox.
Note: Edward Jenner discovered the smallpox vaccine in 1796, the first vaccine to be discovered. He also coined the term vaccination.

text: Who is referred to as the father of Indian medicine? Susruta Charaka Chanakya Vaghbhatt
explanation:
:
Charaka is the father of Indian medicine. He wrote the Charaka Samhita.
Note: Susruta is known as the father of Indian surgery. He is depicted in the following image.

text: Who was responsible for the first codification of medical practice? Aristotle Hippocrates Socrates Hammurabi
explanation:
:
Hammurabi, a Mesopotamian king was responsible for the first codification of medical practice.
Known as the Babylonian Code, it contained laws for the conduct of physicians, health practices, costs, and penalties of harmful therapy.

text: Who is known as the first true epidemiologist in the history of medicine? Hippocrates Susruta Louis Pasteur John Snow
explanation:
:
Hippocrates is known as the first true epidemiologist in the history of medicine. He is also known as the father of medicine.
He introduced the concept of the relationship between the environment and human health. He was the author of Airs, Water, and Places, a treatise on social medicine and hygiene as well as the Corpus Hippocraticum, a collection of 72 volumes of clinical case histories.
He also developed the Hippocratic Oath, which is considered the keystone of medical ethics.

text: Who compiled the 21 volume encyclopedia known as 'the Canon of Medicine'? Andreas Vesalius Avicenna Hippocrates John Snow
explanation:
:
Avicenna compiled the book, the Canon of Medicine which is a 21 volume encyclopedia.
He was a Persian who was also known as lbn Sina. He was the leader of Arabic medicine. The Arabs invented the art of prescription writing.

text: Who was the mastermind behind the great medical work, Fabrica? Andreas Vesalius Ambroise Paré Joseph Lister Ferdinand Cohn
explanation:
:
Andreas Vesalius' work is called the de humani corporis Fabrica. He is regarded as the father of modern anatomy.

text: The father of public health is: Tuberculosis John Snow Cholera Hippocrates
explanation:
:
The father of public health is cholera, the disease, not a person.
John Snow studied the epidemiology of cholera in London from 1848 to 1854 and established the role of polluted drinking water in the spread of cholera. He is called the father of modern epidemiology. He also calculated the dose of ether and chloroform as surgical anesthesia.


Note: Tuberculosis is called the barometer of social welfare.

text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries: 1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b
explanation:
:
The discoveries of the given scientists are as follows:
John Snow - association of cholera with polluted water
Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination
Louis Pasteur - the germ theory of disease
James Lind - prevention of scurvy by intake of citrus fruits
Louis Pasteur was the first to advance the germ theory of disease, which stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. This theory was later expanded by Robert Koch, who put forth Koch's postulates.
Pasteur is also known for the following contributions:
Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation
Developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera
Pioneer of techniques of pasteurization and sterilization The following images show Pasteur and Lind respectively:

text: Who was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848? Joseph Lister James Lind William Farr Edwin Chadwick
explanation:
:
Edwin Chadwick was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848.
He was an English lawyer during the 1832 cholera epidemic. He compiled a report on the Sanitary Condition of the Labouring Population in Great Britain that eventually led to the passing of this act. It is considered a landmark act in the history of public health.

text: Identify the scientist who showed that anthrax was caused by a bacteria. Robert Koch Edward Jenner James Lind John Snow
explanation:
:
Robert Koch discovered that anthrax was caused by bacteria.
He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. He won the Nobel prize in Physiology in 1905.
He also proposed Koch's postulates linking specific microorganisms to specific diseases. They state that the microorganism must be:
Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent
The following images show Robert Koch and his drawing of the anthrax bacillus:

text: In 1902, it was discovered that malaria was transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. Who was behind this discovery? Ronald Ross Charles Alphonse Laveran Walter Reed David Bruce
explanation:
:
Ronald Ross showed that malaria was transmitted by Anopheles mosquito. Option B: Charles Alphonse Laveran discovered the malarial parasite.
Option C: Walter Reed showed that yellow fever transmitted by Aedes mosquito.
Option D: David Bruce showed that African sleeping sickness/trypanosomiasis transmitted by the tsetse fly.

text: The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease was: TB bacillus Anthrax bacillus Leprosy bacillus Plague bacillus
explanation:
:

The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease is leprosy bacillus.
In 1873, Armauer Hansen demonstrated Mycobacterium leprae (rod-like bodies) from a leprosy nodule. This is the first time that chronic infectious disease in humans was shown to be related to a bacillus.
In 1876, Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax.

text: Max Joseph von Pettenkofer described the concept of: Multi-factorial causation of disease Supernatural theory of disease Spontaneous generation theory Theory of web of causation
explanation:
:
Pettenkofer of Munich put forth the theory of multifactorial causation of disease. Other theories of causation of disease include:
Spontaneous generation theory - given by Aristotle
Web of causation theory - given by MacMahon and Pugh
Supernatural theory of disease

text: In which country was the last case of naturally occurring smallpox in the world recorded? India Chile Somalia New Zealand
explanation:
:
The last case of naturally occurring smallpox was in Somalia in 1977.
The last case of smallpox occurred in 1978 when a medical photographer was accidentally exposed to the smallpox virus in a research laboratory in Birmingham.
India was declared smallpox-free on 24th May 1975. WHO declared smallpox as eradicated globally on 8th May 1980.

text: Who first coined the term social medicine? John Ryle Jules Guérin Alfred Grotjahn Francis Albert Eley Crew
explanation:
:
Jules Guérin coined this term as editor of the Gazette médicale de Paris. He was a French orthopaedist in the mid-1800s.
Option A: John Ryle promoted social medicine in England in the early 1900s.
Option C: Alfred Grotjahn described social pathology, the social factors influencing diseases.
Option D: Francis Albert Eley Crew stated that social medicine stood on the pillars of medicine and sociology.

text: How would you define socialized medicine? Subsidized medical care at government's expense Free medical care provided and regulated by government alone Free medical care at government expense, regulated by professional groups Integration of social medicine with health care
explanation:
:
Socialized medicine is the provision of medical service at the government's expense but is operated and regulated by professional groups, and not the government. Russia was the first

country to completely socialize medicine.
Free medical care by a government alone is called state medicine.

text: All of the following are true about socialized medicine except: Ensures social equity and universal coverage Reduces competition among physicians Use state funds for free medicine Promotes utilization of health facilities
explanation:
:
Increasing the utilization of health services is not a component of socialized medicine.
It refers to the provision of medical service through the state funds; however, it is operated and regulated by professional groups. Russia was the first to completely socialize medicine.
It eliminates competition among physicians as well as ensures social equity and universal health coverage.

text: Who said that the secret of national health lies in the homes of people? Florence Nightingale Indira Gandhi Abraham Lincoln Joseph Bore
explanation:
:
Florence Nightingale said that the secret of national health lies in the homes of people. She is considered the the founder of modern nursing.

Answer Key




Detailed Explanations
Solution to Question 1:
According to the WHO, health is “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity”.
In recent years, the definition has been modified to also include the ability to lead a “socially and economically productive life.”



Solution to Question 2:
The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by Louis Pasteur.
The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural determinants of health.
The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism to the environment.
The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, psychological, cultural and economic factors as well.
The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health.

Solution to Question 3:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator.
A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.
Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.



Solution to Question 4:
Number of days of restricted activity is a disability indicator.
Morbidity is defined as public health outcomes focusing on diseases, traumas, or injury. Morbidity indicators can be used to measure the overall health and extent of healthcare utilisation in a given population.
Disability is defined as public health outcomes related to health conditions that include limitations in personal activities and societal participation. There are two types of disability indicators as follows:
Event type indicators-
Number of days of restricted activity
Bed disability days
Work loss days (or school loss days) within a specified period
Person type indicators-
Limitation of mobility: e.g confined to bed
Limitation of activity: e.g limitation to perform the basic activities of daily living such as eating and going to the toilet



Solution to Question 5:
HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality.
HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states.
Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death. As HALE includes not just disability but the larger definition of poor health, it is a better option with respect to the question.

Solution to Question 6:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the burden of disease in the community. It signifies the proportion of all deaths that can be attributed to the disease.
It is calculated as follows:
Proportional mortality rate of a disease = (No. of deaths due to that disease in the year/ Total no. of deaths in the year) *100.
Option A: Case fatality rate measures the risk of persons dying from a certain disease within a given time period. It measures the killing power of a disease. It is used to link mortality to morbidity.
Option B: Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. It is not influenced by the duration of the disease. The use of incidence is generally restricted to acute diseases.
Option C: Crude death rate is considered a fair indicator of the comparative health of the people. It is the rate of total deaths in a year compared to the mid-year population.



Solution to Question 7:
Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population. It is also the best measure of the effectiveness of interventions.
DALY is calculated as - Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost to disability (YLD). It can measure both mortality and disability together.
As DALY is affected by premature loss of life, conditions that affect younger individuals like road traffic accidents have a high DALY. In comparison to this, Alzheimer's disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age and so has a lower YLL.



Solution to Question 8:
Bed disability days is not a utilisation rate. It is an event-type disability indicator. It is defined as the number of days a person spent in a hospital bed due to illness or injury.
Health utilisation rate is defined as the number of people making use of the available health services to the total number of individuals in that population.
Health utilisation rates include:
Proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization
(EPI)
Proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery
Percentage of population using family planning methods

Bed occupancy rate
Average length of stay in the hospita
Bed turnover ratio



Solution to Question 9:
For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be slightly positive.
Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is
left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.



Solution to Question 10:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is a very sensitive indicator.
Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000
It is also one of the best indicators of state failure. It is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live.
Note: The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.



Solution to Question 11:
QALY(Quality Adjusted Life Years) is used in assessing the cost-effectiveness (value of money) of a medical intervention. It is a measure of both the quality and quantity of life lived. It indicates the number of years of life that would be added by the intervention.



Solution to Question 12:
Lifestyle is a behavioural and socio-cultural determinant of health. It is not a socio-economic determinant.
Socio-economic determinants of health are the following:
Economic status (per capita GNP)
Education
Occupation
Political system

Lifestyle is simply the way people live. It reflects our social values, attitudes, and activities. It is composed of:
Cultural patterns (daily nutrition, superstitions)
Behavioral patterns (personal hygiene, sedentary life)
Lifelong personal habits (e.g. smoking, alcoholism)
Lifestyle is learned by social interaction with parents, siblings, friends, school, and mass media.
Our political system determines our health. It can help shape community health services with regards to resource allocation, manpower policy, choice of technology, and the degree to which these services are made available & accessible to all segments of the society.
The percentage of GDP spent on health is an indicator of political commitment. WHO recommends at least 5% of GDP to be spent on health care. India spends about 2.1 % of its GDP on health(budget 2022-23).



Solution to Question 13:
Annual family income is not a socioeconomic indicator of health. Socio-economic indicators of health (mnemonic: H – FLAGGED):
Housing (number of persons per room)
Family size
Literacy rate (especially female literacy rate)
Availability of per capita calorie
GNP per capita
Growth rate of population
UnEmployment leve
Dependency ratio



Solution to Question 14:
The provision of free health camps by the government is a concept of state medicine.
Health does not merely mean the absence of disease or provision of diagnostic, curative, and preventive services. It is a state of physical, mental, and social well-being.
The state of positive health is based on the idea of perfect functioning of the body and mind. According to this concept, health is:
Biologically a state in which every cell and organ in the body is functioning at optimum capacity
Psychologically a state in which the individual feels a sense of perfect well-being and mastery over his environment

Socially a state in which the individual's capacities for participation in the social system are optima
This concept is too idealistic and can never become a reality. Humans can never be so perfectly adapted to the environment because everything in our life is subject to change.
As the goal of positive health is unattainable, a broader concept of improving the quality of life has emerged. This highlights that positive health depends on medical action and also on economic, cultural, and social factors in the community.



Solution to Question 15:
Social security is a component of the level of living as per the United Nations and not standard of living.
According to the WHO, the standard of living includes:
Income and occupation
Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition
Level of provision of health, educational, and recreational services It depends on per capita GNP.


Solution to Question 16:
Infant mortality rate, literacy rate, and life expectancy at 1 year of age are the components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI).



Solution to Question 17:
Human development index (HDI) is the best measure of the standard of living of a population. Physical quality of life index (PQLI) measures the quality of life.


Solution to Question 18:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is not a component of HDI. It is a component of the physical quality of life index (PQLI).
The human development index (HDI) is used to compare living standards in different countries. It includes the following dimensions or components:
Each dimension index is calculated using the formula: Dimension Index = (Actual Value -
Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value)

HDI is the geometric mean of the three indices: ILife1/3 x	IEducation1/3	x	IIncome1/3.
As per the Human Development Report 2023-2024, India's Human Development Index (HDI)
value is 0.644. This places India at 134th out of 193 countries.




Solution to Question 19:
The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years and the maximum is 85 years.
These minimum and maximum values are used to calculate the dimension indices in HDI and are called goalposts.
Each dimension index is calculated using the formula:
Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value).



Solution to Question 20:
The gross enrollment ratio is no longer used in obtaining the education index in HDI. It was used as an indicator earlier.
The education index is calculated by taking into account the mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling. Maximum and minimum values are based on global data.
Adult literacy rate and gross enrollment ratio were used as indicators before 2009.



Solution to Question 21:
Human poverty index (HPI) measures deprivation in basic dimensions of human development.
HPI-1 is used for developing countries and HPI-2 is used for developed countries. It is based upon the following indicators:
The range of HPI is from 0 to 100. The term HPI has now been replaced with multidimensional poverty index (MPI).

Building social security is not included in the Ottawa charter for health promotion.
The first international conference for health promotion was held in Ottawa on 21st Nov 1986. It produced a charter known as the Ottawa charter.
The charter identified five key action areas as given below:
Build healthy public policy
Create supportive environment for health
Strengthen community action for health
Develop personal skills
Reorient health services

Solution to Question 1:
Duration of illness is not a part of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis. The epidemiological triad includes host, agent and environment:
Host factors: Age, sex, religion, race, genetic profile, immune system
Agent factors:
Biological - bacteria, viruses
Chemical - poisons, alcohol, smoke
Physical - trauma, fire, radiation
Nutrition - lack/excess
Environmental factors:
Temperature, humidity, altitude
Water, milk, food
Radiation, pollution, noise
Crowding, housing, neighborhood



Hence, a malnourished child (host), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (agent) and overcrowding
(environment) form the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis.





Solution to Question 2:
Disease  Impairment  Disability  Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given options.
Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction. Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function. Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.
Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal.





Solution to Question 3:
The correctly matched events relating to the given example are as follows:
The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function". E.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a secondary impairment as well.
The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of impairment, the affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities and hence the person is considered disabled.
According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped.


Solution to Question 4:
The web of causation for a disease suggests a number of ways to interrupt the disease occurrence/progression.
This model was suggested by MacMahon and Pugh in their book ‘Epidemiologic Principles and Methods’.
Web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited in the study of chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed. Sometimes removal of one significant link is sufficient to control the disease.
In a multifactorial event, individual factors are by no means of equal weightage. The importance of each factor is expressed in terms of relative risk.



Solution to Question 5:
Primary prevention is not possible in the pathogenesis period of a disease. It can only be done in the period of pre-pathogenesis.
The two phases in the natural history of a disease include:
Period of pre-pathogenesis: It is before the onset of disease in humans. The disease agent has not entered the host, but the factors favouring the disease already exist. Primary
prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
Period of pathogenesis: It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death or disability. Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period. It isn't always characterised by the presence of disease symptoms as it also includes subclinical cases.

Solution to Question 8:
Interruption in the transmission of a disease is called elimination. It is a step towards eradication.
Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.
Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required.
Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.
Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.



Solution to Question 9:

Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization, goes a long way in helping the elimination of diseases. When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease.
The purpose of isolation is to protect the community by preventing the transfer of infection from the reservoir to the possible susceptible hosts. Quarantine refers to restrictions on the healthy contacts of an infectious disease.

Solution to Question 16:
Adoption of a healthy lifestyle from childhood would fall under the category of primordial prevention of coronary artery disease.
Primordial prevention is preventing the emergence of risk factors among population groups in which these risk factors have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems (obesity, hypertension) have their early origins in childhood. It is in childhood that lifestyles are formed i.e. eating patterns, physical exercise, smoking, etc.
In primordial prevention, efforts are made to discourage children from adopting harmful lifestyles.
These lifestyle changes when made by adults are known as primary prevention.



Solution to Question 17:
Prescriptive screening of a disease is an example of secondary prevention.
Prescriptive screening of disease can lead to early diagnosis of disease. By early diagnosis, intervention can be made to prevent disability. Hence, it comes under secondary prevention.



Solution to Question 18:

Prospective screening is a type of primary prevention.
Prospective screening is done on healthy individuals to screen for disease. It is done prior to the onset of the disease. E.g., screening donated blood for HIV before it is transfused. This type of prevention reduces the incidence of disease.
Note: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are screened for their own benefits. It is an early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. E.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
